language.name: c
language.overview: C is one of the oldest programming languages of the computer history. It's defined as a high-level programming language but however you can embed Assembly code into your program. It's the best choice for writing system drivers. It can be also used to write operating system kernels and many more.

pros.item: Can embed Assembly (and so you can interact directly with the CPU and the hardware)
Cross-platform
Fast
It can also be used to write operating system kernels (Linux is an example) or system drivers
Native (doesn't have any emulation or virtual machine like Java or Mono C# to be run)

cons.item: Cross-platform programs may need some changes in order to be compiled correctly from different compilers
It's a bit difficult
Some Assembly knowledge needed to understand and write well-written programs

language.name: cpp
language.overview: C++ is an improvement of the C programming language. Unlike C it's an object oriented programming language but it implements all C standard features anyway. It can be used to write also operating system kernels and system drivers just like C but it has a different linkage.

pros.item: Easier than C
Object-oriented, unlike C

cons.item: Source linkage changes between different compilers

language.name: cs
language.overview: C# is a object oriented programming language developed by Microsoft. It's syntax is very easy but much similar to C. It has an extensive set of default libraries and classes which can be used in your own program. Currently it's possible to run C# programs also on Linux and MacOS thanks to Mono which is also used by Unity Game Engine.

pros.item: Cross-platform thanks to Mono (only Mono compiled program are cross-platform)
Easy to code
Lots of integrated libraries

cons.item: Cross-platform is not native. To run C# Cross-Platform programs you need to install the Mono Runtime module
Not very fast with Mono

language.name: html
language.overview: First of all, it isn't actually a programming language. It's a markup language. Hypertext Markup Language (commonly abbreviated as HTML) is the standard markup language used to create webpages. Web browsers render HTML files into visible and viewable webpages. CSS was released four years after the HTML. If you're going to learn HTML, CSS is a highly recommended extra, your webpages will look a lot less plain.

pros.item: Consistency throughout, HTML can be found almost everywhere on the Web
Many built-in tags
Neater code, naming convention gives developers easier understanding of what does what

cons.item: Only modern browsers support HTML5, this knocks HTML5 out for older ones
Time-consuming, due to inefficiency of maintaining a pure static HTML website

language.name: java
language.overview: Java is everywhere, literally. It's a general purpose language, meaning that you can use it for any kind of development. It's actually one of the most used programming languages in the world. Java is derived from C and C++, initially developed in 1995 at Sun Microsystems. You can find Java almost anywhere nowadays.

pros.item: Built-in garbage collection, automatically throws away objects not being used anymore
Has a very large built-in standard library
Syntax is similar to that of C++, except it's more simplified

cons.item: Development takes more time compared to other languages (e.g. PHP, Python, Ruby)
Strict with everything (may be a good thing to certain people)

language.name: javascript
language.overview: JavaScript is one of the core technologies in producing content for the World Wide Web. It first appeared in 1995, and is still widely used today. The language is imperative and structured, dynamically-typed, and object-oriented. It can also be used to create server-side applications, if you know what Node.js is.

pros.item: Executed on the client side, which means you don't have to worry about your server being overworked
Easy to pickup, syntax is similar to the English language
Webpages can be easily extended

cons.item: Can be easily exploited by malicious users
Rendered differently throughout different browsers

language.name: php
language.overview: PHP is a server-side scripting language made for web development, but can also be used for many other purposes. It was made in 1994, initially PHP was an acronym that stood for Personal Home Pages. It now stands for PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor. Can be embedded into HTML.

pros.item: Easy-to-use scripting language (for servers and task automation)
Relatively easy to learn, also popular and common
Similar to the C language, will be easier for programmers that know C

cons.item: Function names are inconsistent
Unpredictable typing system

language.name: python
language.overview: Python is a high-level, interpreted, and dynamic scripting language. It focuses on code readability, requiring less lines of code to complete tasks when compared to languages like C++ and Java. Python is also widely used, from the simplest scripts to industrial applications.

pros.item: Easily read and written
Great language to learn as your first programming language
No need to compile code to run it
Standard library has mostly everything you'll need

cons.item: Currently limited to desktop applications, not used in mobile development
Security is an issue, if you don't want the source code to be viewed when distributed
Slower when compared to compiled languages like C++ and Java

language.name: scratch
language.overview: Scratch is ideal for individuals with very little or no programming experience. It helps you develop the mindset of a programmer, and teaches you the basics of programming. Great for beginners of all ages.

pros.item: Ability to make things you would be able to make with real code
Beginner-friendly environment
Simple user interface allows you to start coding instantly

cons.item: Limited, only meant as a language to help you grasp programming concepts

language.name: swift
language.overview: Swift is a programming language designed by Apple, for iOS, macOS, watchOS, tvOS, and Linux. It's a general purpose language, also a more modern alternative to Objective-C. Swift also draws ideas from many different programming languages.

pros.item: Easier and faster for programmers to learn
Easy to read and write, shorter code length overall
Friendly for beginners, compared to Objective-C

cons.item: Compatible with only some platforms
Fast-paced development on the language, many updates bring about large changes
